## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Continued Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-04-27T12:48:00Z
## Message ID: 20170427-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux continues to be above 10^5 pfu, first starting at 2017-04-23T15:05Z and crossing most recently at  2017-04-27T06:35Z. See previous notifications 20170423-AL-002 and 20170425-AL-001.

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by the high speed stream starting at 2017-04-18T18:02Z and the high speed stream starting at 2017-04-21T11:20Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2017-04-23T15:05:00-RBE-001. 

## Notes:

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for April 19, 2017 - April 25, 2017
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-04-26T20:47:53Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2017-04-19T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2017-04-25T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20170426-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low to moderate levels during this reporting period.  There were 2 C-type CMEs (see details below).   

Geomagnetic activity was at moderate levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=6 for the reporting period.  Geomagnetic Kp index has reached level 6 (moderate) during the synoptic periods of 2017-04-20T03:00Z-06:00Z, 2017-04-22T03:00Z-06:00Z, 2017-04-22T12:00Z-15:00Z, 2017-04-22T21:00Z-24:00Z, and 2017-04-23T06:00Z-09:00Z.  The enhancement in geomagnetic activity was associated with a couple of coronal hole high speed streams detected by DSCOVR at L1 around 2017-04-18 and 2017-04-21, respectively.  The second one was possibly combined with a glancing blow of a transient that started on 2017-04-18T19:48Z.  Solar wind speeds reached very high values on 2017-04-23 with values of >750 km/s (see notifications 20170420-AL-001, 20170420-AL-002, 20170422-AL-001, 20170422-AL-002, 20170423-AL-001).  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux in the Earth's outer radiation belt crossed the threshold level of 10^5 pfu starting at 2017-04-23T15:05Z. These significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt detected by GOES 13 were associated with the coronal hole high speed streams described above (see notification 20170423-AL-002 and 20170425-AL-001).  Fluxes are still currently elevated.  

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV were at background levels for the entire reporting period.  

There was a solar energetic particle event detected by STEREO A.  The flux of 13-100 MeV protons exceeded 10^(-1) pfu/MeV starting at 2017-04-18T23:39Z.  This solar energetic particle event was associated with a C5.5 class-flare with from the active region 12651 and the CME that started 2017-04-18T19:48Z  (see notifications 20170419-AL-001 and 20170419-AL-002, and 20170419-AL-003).  

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the due to the solar energetic particle event detected by STEREO A and the elevation in the electron fluxes at the Earth's outer radiation belt described above.  

##Events:
Flares (M-class and above)
Date         Start     Stop      Peak      Class   Location         
None Observed  

CMEs (>500 km/s):

Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2017-04-20T22:09Z     ~719            C               -10/34                34                          STEREO A, SOHO                    


Non-Earth directed:
Starting time        Speed (km/s)   Type   Direction (LON/LAT in HEEQ)   Half-Angle width (degrees)  Detecting spacecraft (real-time)  
2017-04-23T06:00Z     ~911            C               -66/-3                23                          SOHO, STEREO A                    
 

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2017-04-26T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2017-05-02T23:59Z

Solar activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week.  The active regions on the Earth's facing side of the solar disk are currently producing low classification solar flares and coronal mass ejections.   Geomagnetic activity was elevated during the reporting period, but it is expected to go back to nominal levels in the next few days.   

## Notes: 
SCORE CME typification system:
S-type: CMEs with speeds less than 500 km/s
C-type: Common 500-999 km/s
O-type: Occasional 1000-1999 km/s
R-type: Rare 2000-2999 km/s
ER-type: Extremely Rare >3000 km/s
http://swc.gsfc.nasa.gov/main/score

## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for April 12, 2017 - April 18, 2017
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-04-19T20:31:44Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2017-04-12T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2017-04-18T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20170419-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low to moderate levels during this reporting period.  There were 3 C-type CMEs (see details below).   Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center, it was estimated that the CME starting on 2017-04-18T19:48Z may impact Spitzer at 2017-04-21T02:26Z, Mars at 2017-04-23T18:00Z (glancing blow), and STEREO A at 2017-04-21T20:00Z (glancing blow) (plus minus 7 hours). This CME event is associated with a C5.5 flare starting on 2017-04-18T19:15Z from solar active region 12651 (see notification 20170419-AL-003). 

Geomagnetic activity was below minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=4 for the reporting period.   An arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream was detected by DSCOVR/ACE around 2017-04-18. The arrival elevated the geomagnetic activity to a Kp=5 for the synoptic period of 2017-04-19T03:00Z-06:00Z.  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. 

Solar energetic particle event was detected by STEREO A. The flux of 13-100 MeV protons exceeded 10^(-1) pfu/MeV starting at 2017-04-18T23:39Z.  This event was associated with the C5.5. flare from active region 12651 and the CME starting at 2017-04-18T19:48Z described above (see notifications 20170419-AL-001 and 20170419-AL-002).  

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES was at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the solar energetic particle event detected by STEREO A described above.

## Space Weather Outlook:
## Outlook Coverage Begin Date: 2017-04-19T00:00Z 
## Outlook Coverage End Date:  2017-04-25T23:59Z

The solar activity is expected to be low to moderate for the upcoming week.  The active region 12651, which is just rotating to the Earth's facing side, is currently producing solar flares and coronal mass ejections.   Geomagnetic activity was slightly elevated on 2017-04-19 due to the arrival of a small coronal hole high speed stream described above.  The geomagnetic activity will enhance within the next several days due to the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream located near the center disk.

## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - CME (Spitzer, Mars, STEREO A)
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-04-19T14:23:49Z
## Message ID: 20170419-AL-003
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

C-type CME detected by STEREO A / SOHO. 

Start time of the event: 2017-04-18T19:48Z.

Estimated speed: ~934 km/s.

Estimated opening half-angle: 50 deg.

Direction (lon./lat.): -76/21 in Heliocentric Earth Equatorial coordinates (see [1] in Notes).

Activity ID: 2017-04-18T19:48:00-CME-001

Based on preliminary heliospheric modeling carried out at NASA GSFC Space Weather Research Center, it is estimated that the CME may impact Spitzer, Mars (glancing blow), and STEREO A (glancing blow).  The leading edge or flank of the CME will reach Spitzer at 2017-04-21T02:26Z, Mars at 2017-04-23T18:00Z, and STEREO A at 2017-04-21T20:00Z (plus minus 7 hours). The associated SEP event could also affect MAVEN.

## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for April 05, 2017 - April 11, 2017
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-04-12T19:16:13Z

##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at low levels during this reporting period.  There was 1 C-type CME (see details below).   

Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5 for the reporting period.  The highest value of Kp=5 occurred during the synoptic period of 2017-04-09T03:00Z-06:00Z.  This slight increase in geomagnetic activity was associated with a coronal hole high speed solar wind stream detected by DSCOVR at L1 around 2017-04-07.  Solar wind speed reached values of >600 km/s on 2017-04-08.

On 2017-04-06 the STEREO A IMPACT/PLASTIC instruments detected the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream.  The solar wind speed reached values of >600 km/s by 2017-04-07.  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained below the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for the entire reporting period. They have been slightly elevated by 2017-04-12 to values of about 60,000 pfu possibly due to the coronal hole high speed stream described above.  

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period. 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low this week.

## Message Type: Weekly Space Weather Summary Report for March 29, 2017 - April 04, 2017
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-04-05T23:48:59Z
## Report Coverage Begin Date: 2017-03-29T00:00Z
## Report Coverage End Date: 2017-04-04T23:59Z
## Message ID: 20170405-7D-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Solar activity was at very high levels during this reporting period with 7 M-class flares (see list below).  There were 3 C-type CMEs (see details below).   

Geomagnetic activity was at minor levels with Kp index (a measure of geomagnetic activity, ranging 0-9) <=5 for the reporting period.  The highest value of Kp=5 occurred during the synoptic periods of 2017-03-30T03:00Z-06:00Z, 2017-03-30T21:00Z to 2017-03-31T09:00Z, and 2017-04-04T06:00Z-12:00Z.  The slight enhancement in geomagnetic activity on 2017-04-04 was possibly associated with the glancing blow of a transient arriving on the same day associated with the M4.4 class-flare from active region 12644 on 2017-04-01 with a possible combination with a small coronal hole high speed stream.  

The > 0.8 MeV energetic electron flux detected at GOES remained above the threshold level of 10^5 pfu for almost the entire reporting period starting on 2017-03-28 due to the arrival of a coronal hole high speed stream detected by DSCOVR at L1 around 2017-03-27 (see notifications 20170328-AL-001, 20170328-AL-002, 20170330-AL-001, 20170401-AL-001, and 20170403-AL-001).  Currently on 2017-04-05, levels are going back to nominal values.  

The energetic proton flux of >10 MeV protons detected at GOES and the 13-100 MeV protons at STEREO A were all at background levels for the entire reporting period 

Space Weather Impact:
Space weather impacts on NASA spacecraft are expected to have been low to moderate this week due to the electron flux enhancement on the Earth's outer radiation belt described above and the solar flare activity.

## NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Space Weather Research Center ( SWRC )
## Message Type: Space Weather Notification - Continued Radiation Belt Enhancement
##
## Message Issue Date: 2017-04-03T12:05:59Z
## Message ID: 20170403-AL-001
##
## Disclaimer: NOAA's Space Weather Prediction Center (http://swpc.noaa.gov) is the United States Government official source for space weather forecasts. This "Experimental Research Information" consists of preliminary NASA research products and should be interpreted and used accordingly.


## Summary:

Significantly elevated energetic electron fluxes in the Earth's outer radiation belt. GOES 13 "greater than 0.8 MeV" integral electron flux first crossed above the 10^5 pfu threshold starting at 2017-03-28T15:00Z. Elevated electron flux levels have continued with the most recent crossing at 2017-04-03T10:10Z. See recent notifications  20170328-AL-002, 20170330-AL-001, & 20170401-AL-001.

The elevated energetic electron flux levels are caused by the high speed stream starting at 2017-03-27T00:00Z.

NASA spacecraft at GEO, MEO and other orbits passing through or in the vicinity of the Earth's outer radiation belt can be impacted.

Activity ID: 2017-03-28T15:00:00-RBE-001.
